title: German Consumer Prices Tick Higher in October But Data Isn't a Game-Changer
text:
By Emese Bartha

FRANKFURT--German consumer prices ticked higher in October, topping forecasts of unchanged reading, nonetheless still providing no signs of a pickup toward the European Central Bank's target.

Consumer prices rose by 0.1% on the month in October, measured by both national and EU-harmonized standards, the Federal Statistical Office said Wednesday. Economists in The Wall Street Journal's survey forecast unchanged prices, according to both measures.

Consumer prices were up by 1.1% on the year, measured according to national standards, in line with economists' forecast. Prices were up by 0.9%, according to EU-harmonized standards, compared with The Wall Street Journal's forecast of 0.8%.

The annual inflation rate continues to be pushed lower by falling energy prices, which were down by 2.1% on the year in October, data from the Federal Statistical Office showed.

The European Central Bank announced a package of easing measures in September, aiming to push inflation higher toward its target of below but close to 2%.

Write to Emese Bartha at emese.bartha@wsj.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 30, 2019 09:31 ET (13:31 GMT)
